title: Adversarial Collaboration Contest 2019
summary:
Key ideas
- The second annual Adversarial Collaboration Contest has been announced.
- Adversarial collaboration involves two people with opposing views collaborating to create a summary of evidence for and against a thesis, with the aim of giving readers a balanced view.
- Entries should focus on a controversial topic and come to a unified conclusion.
- The essay should be similar in length and tone to one of the author's Much More Than You Wanted To Know essays.
- Prize money will depend on the number of entrants and will likely be around $2500.

Key learnings
- The contest allows people with opposing views to work together to produce a more balanced summary of the evidence for debates on controversial topics.
- The winning entry will be determined by a poll of SSC readers and the author's vote counting for 10 percentage points.
- The author encourages entries from a range of fields, not just political issues.

Key questions
- What does the author mean by "taboo topics" and how might these be handled in the contest?
- How will the author determine the level of quality required for an entry to meet the minimum level of quality to be published on SSC?
- How will the author ensure the entrants maintain a united front in their essay, and what happens if they fail to do so?
